comments.body: Yeah, it's so horrible for mapmaking Xd

/gamerule doDaylightCycle 1

 

I kid; this looks like a good idea; just be more specific in what you mean by more options for the other gamerules.
I appreciate and fully support the idea, but I would add player-specific gamerules. Ex. /gamerule doImmediateRespawn @s

I'm fully your opinion. I'm a Minecraft Bedrock Edition Addon developer and it would save a lot of time by simply do this in-game instead of using 3rd party external software which relies on the community. It would be also way more convenient by just having a build-in mechanic just like in java edition. Hopefully Mojang will ever listen to its community again instead of staying inside of their own bubble. this is a feature for what the community is waiting for years now.

Yes. We finally need NBT in Bedrock. There are so many things that are harder to do because I cannot use NBT data. Things like making an unbreakable tool or summon/giving an item/mob attributes. It is one reason I don't like playing Bedrock.
This would be incredibly useful for loads of different things. I'm trying to lock item frames and cetain things in my bedrock server and I literally don't know how else to do this without NBT data.
We could have prefixes like [Admin], [MVP+] or just misc prefixes like [Gamer], eg
For the little ones
This would be useful for disabled people
This is 4 years old now. Why is this still not a feature? especially with block displays not being in the game.
I think this idea is very interesting, especially to implement in the latest version of Java Edition, which is very focused on entity riding. It would be really useful. Thanks.

A better syntax would probably be /tag <targets> clear instead of /tag <targets> removeAll.

Other than that, there is no official way to clear an entity's tag list, so this would be a welcome addition.
I would love to see this in Minecraft! It would be so useful especially if you use the tag command all the time!

God yes. I have so many tags and I'm tired of adding any new ones to the remove all tags function. Can we also get a remove all scoreboards (I know it's weird but it's easier to delete and re-create than clear all values of every one) command? These are such basic principal functions that we lack for literally no reason.
I feel like the command in the suggestion above with `/tag <targets> clear` would be the way to go, otherwise, similar to scoreboard reset, use * to select all. `/tag <targets> remove *`
this would be sooooo helpfull

Please add this!

Clearing player tags one by one is a real hassle. At least for entities we can use the `data modify/merge` command to do so but for player it's not really possible and since i'm working with real-time computed tags it hard to always keep track of them.

definitely needs to be added, and also more coding features, like receiving output from commands and variables and sending output, if/else if/else/if not, making mcfunction more of a coding language than just Minecraft commands in a sequence

Absolutely needed! Functions can use data from molang queries. Especially if they are expanded like https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360050574612--Bedrock-Implementing-more-MoLang-queries-and-how-useful-it-is-

There should be an option to set the amount of time a day lasts in a world in the game settings for individual worlds.    The option should be very customizable so you can set any amount of time a day lasts in a world.

I completely agree with this! I've been playing a lot of Minecraft lately, and sometimes I feel like it'd be really nice to change the daylight cycle to be 40 minutes, rather than 20.

Sure, you can use a Command Block, but that's a bit obnoxious, and not very friendly towards less technical players. (and frankly, I just don't want to have any Command Blocks in my Survival Worlds :p )
We need this because lately it feels like the day/night cycle has been shortened. I wish I could have long days or if I'm in the mood to fight some monsters long nights.

Completely agree, I would make this a gamerule.

I find it super annoying to have to go to my bed to sleep every 10 minutes as I'm working on a build.
I think being able to select from several time options would be nice.

Someone mentioned using a command block, but no, if you use a command block it ends up causing the skybox to stutter. I've had mods that alter the time speed have the same issue as well. It's far from perfect as is.
Agreed except use the java syntax instead of that weird custom syntax

I have't tried  but can you not achieve this with the give command already using nbt?

/give <player>[<selectors>] <item>[<NBT>] [<count>]

Yeah. I don't get why Java edition gets to have all these customization options when you summon fireworks, and us Bedrock users are stuck with just the plain old white trail. I would love the options that they have on Java or at least be able to change the color. Please add this feature, as it would help with creating firework displays without having to have dispensers showing or doing very complicated Redstone.
idk why but that doesn't work for me

So it would be a teleport room with modern technology that allow you to immediately teleport to the named place list or specific coordinate.

but... why?
This is an incredibly useful idea. Not only does it simplify playing sounds, it adds the ability to modify the volume, pitch, and other attributes of the sound.

In my opinion, this is a great idea, albeit a little unnecessary. It follows the same logic that led to the combination of /entitydata and /blockdata into /data, and would be a small step forward in organizing the commands.

I think another option can be a query feature, where you can do /sound query (filters such as the sound or audio track) and it will say the song playing, the audio track it's playing in, who the sound is playing to, and how many ticks the song has been playing.

In conclusion of the whole idea and the comments (and mine):

The command would be

/sound <play | stop | degrade | query>

The arguments would be:

play

Plays a sound. Its syntax would be:

/sound play <sound> <category> <Pos: x and z> <volume> <pitch>
[<nbt>]

In the argument [<nbt>] NBTs are added, examples that I can think of would be:

 

Tags: ["<namespace>"]

Add a label to the sound (a differentiator).

 

Everywhere: 1b

It makes the sound audible in all dimensions and without indicating where it comes from (in the subtitles and in the stereo speakers).

 

EndTrigger: [<nbt>]

Execute the specified at the end of the playback:

{"RunCommand":"<command>"}

Run the command specified in the space "<command>"

{"Sounds":[<nbt>]}

Play randomly sounds in NBT format or using a data storage (for multiple repeating times) with the next syntax:

{sound:[<sound>],nbts:[<nbt>],weight:<number>,schedule:<schedule name>}

The weight tag is the exactly the same thing like in the loot tables (if the sound have weight 0, it don't gonna plays or taken in the pool), the sound tag specifies what sound will be reproduced, the schedule tag make if the schedule return false, the weight of the sound is automatically returned 0.

Or in case of use a data storage:

{"storage":"<name of the data storage>"}

I don't much of programming but I think Mojang can do all of this if take the sounds like to a storage (A list of all the sounds with his tags, pos, ticks of reproduce, volume, pitches), the unique thing is the sound engine
When you also add parameters to modify fade in and fade out times, it would be a great feature

There are some ideas here that I can support.

Generally, shrinking the two seperate commands down into one is a good idea which also opens the possibility of adding new mechanics to it, like either the modify or query command.

How much use it actually has being able to modify volume, pitch and minimum volume afterwards is a viable question - fading in/out functionality alone would do wonders but this is already the topic of another thread - and I don't image there being that much actually useful information to query which can be represented as a single, comparable (which means most likely integer) value.

Though having some way of determining when/running some function on a sound effect (or music mostly) ending would also be a very helpful thing, like the suggested "EndTrigger" thingy. If there is just another optional parameter to "/sound play" being like <function name> defining a function to run (as all players hearing the sound) when this playback ends and "/sound stop" to define if we want to trigger this "playback end handler function" on our manual forced playback stop, or some other way to setup such a handler doesn't matter.

One thing a /sound command really needs is an option to loop sounds. I've tried using timers to loop music but as soon as the ticks go below 20 a second it gets really out of sync

Also being able to stop individual sounds as opposed to entire channels would be awesome!

I'm trying to create a mini game world and I need more than 10 ticking areas but I only need each ticking area to be about 3 blocks by 3 block (9 blocks in total) but due to this cap it's very annoying as I don't understand why it can't be a block/chunk limit than a number limit because I think a 1000 chunk limit gives players/ map makers like myself more creativity to expand and delve into than being caped at 10 ticking area which can be max 10 chunks. Please increase/ change the cap as it will benefit minecraft bedrock command users like myself thanks.

-HnR Zomrick

True this would be a great change, not many people are giving this issue the light is deserves as it really holds back the creativity and potential of many creators, hopefully in the future they do something about this rather big issue
Bedrock should get the option of 0 tick in game rules for redstone people who want to follow tutorials it could be like the ui changer with a classic option

In Java Edition, you can press F3 + D to clear your chat quickly.

Other than that, commands currently cannot clear your chat, the only other way is to print 100 new lines to move the existing text out of the way, which isn't ideal, so this is a welcome idea.

But it would need another argument to be effective, a target selector to choose which player to have their chat cleared. For example, /clearchat @p would clear the chat of the nearest player.
Ever heard of F3+D?
yes but this command would also delete the content of the chat of other players. useful on servers

I literally needed that today.

Today I was messing with command blocks and that would have been useful with the text that executes commands. I made an elevator that, when entered would show the buttons as text. Clicking them would teleport the player to one of two places, but I didn't want the player to be able to teleport when being outiside of the elevator. I was able to fix that with "[distance=..12]", but a /clearchat command would be useful to make the elevator menu disappear.

The command could work like that:

/clearchat @p - Clears chat of nearest player.

/clearchat @a @s - Removes all your messages from everyone's chat (If you acidentally sent something you shouldn't).

/clearchat @a @e[type=!player] - Removes messages sent by mobs affected by the "/execute as" command, but doesn't remove messages sent actual players.
